response.answer_text: Deepawali or The festival of lights is indeed a very beautiful festival. With Lights! Lights! Lights! All around, this festival is unique in its own. And the way , I (or any gorkhali ) celebrate this festival called TIHAR is something different from the mainstream diwali. The Deepawali starts with : DAY 1 : “KAAG TIHAR” or worshipping the Crow. Yes!! Crow ! Our diwali does not merely starts worshipping the god or the goddess but we start our deepawali by feeding the crows. Crows and ravens are worshiped by offerings of sweets and dishes placed on the roofs of houses. The cawing of crows and ravens symbolizes sadness and grief in Hinduism, so devotees offer crows and ravens food to avert grief and death in their homes.  Day 2 : “KUKUR TIHAR” or worshipping the DOGS. Yes ! Our 2nd day of deepawali starts with the faithful friends The Dogs. on this day, offerings are being made to the dogs. This is just a smaller way of thanking the faithful service of the dogs towards our social and personal security. Hindu tradition holds that a dog is the guardian and messenger of Yama, the lord and judge of the death. A dog is also said to guard the gates of the afterlife. How do we perfom it : During Kukur Tihar, the mythological and real relationships between humans and dogs constitute the day’s major focus. A garland of flowers is draped around the neck of every dog; not only those with homes, but strays as well. Then a TILAK or TIKO is marked at its forehead.    DAY 3 : GAI TIHAR (COW) AND LAXMI PUJA , The morning of the third day begins with the worshipping of the cows . The cow represents mother earth, prosperity and wealth. She gets a lot of attention all year round. But on this day she gets the best of everything!   LAXMI PUJA : In the evening of the 3rd day, offerings are being placed before goddess Laxmi, the goddess of wealth. Prayers and mantras are being chanted . People decorated their houses with full lightnings and prasads are being given.    After this, starts the festival of the youths : BHAILO AND DEUSI . These are traditional songs sung in groups during deepawali. Bhailo is sung by the girls and Deusi by the boys. BHAILO song goes on like this : “Bhailini aain agana gunyo cholo magna, hey ausi ko din gai tiharo bhailo”. Badali kudali rakheko, laxmi pooja gareko, hey ajako dina gaitiharo bhailo…” (Meaning Bahilini are at your door to ask for a gunyo cholo, Nepali traditional dress ) The youths go on singing these songs from house to house. At the end of the songs, the owner of the house offers food and money to the singers who in return showers blessings upon the family for good health and prosperity. Bhailo is mainly sung on the 3rd day and Deusi on the 4th. Also, from this day onwards people starts cracking the fire crackers. SEL ROTI : The most important element of TIHAR. Our Tihar is incomplete if we don’t have this mouth watering food. It is a traditional home made ring shaped roti. I bet if you try it once, you will love it more than all those Domino’s or Kfc stuffs . Have any nepali friend , ask them about this.     Day 4 : Goru puja (OXEN) or Goverdhan puja On Govardhan puja or Goru Tihar, three different kinds of puja are performed. We perform Goru Puja, or worship Oxen. We also perform Govardhan Puja, which is done by making a hill of govardhan parbat using Cow dung. Cow dung has big importance in Hindu culture. In the old days it was used for everything from light at night to polish mud floors of traditional houses. Still now no Puja is complete without cow dung in Nepali Hindu culture. In the evening many Nepali children and young men go house to house singing Deusi song , which goes like this : “Aahai bhana bhai ho deusi re , he ramari bhana deusere” ( Brothers, let’s sing Deusi , come on say it nicely and entertain the people) Deusi is very similar to Bhailo. However, nowadays there is such distinction. People go in group with males and females members to celebrate Bhailo and deusi both. Deusi team:  Bhailo team :  DAY 5 : BHAI TIKA or BHAI DHUJ , The fifth and last day of Tihar is Bhai Tika. This day sisters put “Tika of five colours” Paanch Rangi Tika - Yellow, green, red, blue and white on forehead of her brothers, to ensure long life and prosperity of her brothers . In return brothers bow down on her feet and also puts a tiko on the sister’s forehead and assures her to protect her and save her from any difficulties . There is also an exchange of gifts as a symbol of love. The TIKO ARRANGMENT :  A Pic from my childhood during this auspicious bhai dhuj , around 12 years back. (I am the one in orange shirt ). My mother and her brother. Me and my sister beside.   Happily with such a wonderful five days celebration, the Deepawali or the Tihar comes to an end. Tihar is not just the attachment of religious sentiments but it represents on a wider scale, the divine attachment between humans and other animals. Sometimes, it amazes me how wonderful are all these festivals. How wonderful our country is !!. How diverse and How awesome it is!! And more awesome are these festivals which make our life more enjoyable. Wishing you all a happy deepawali and a happy Tihar. Thank u :-) JAI HIND!! JAI GORKHA!! Source : My grandfather :-). He is no more but his words and his devotion towards these festivals makes me remember him again and again. Images : Google and wikipedia.

Happy Diwali/Deepavali to all!  (The above picture was taken in early eighties when color photography was newly introduced in India-My husband was sitting on the steps and I was standing at the back and two brothers were standing. Another brother was the one who clicked the photo) Well many people here have written about the religious rituals followed on Diwali and significance of them. So I am not going to repeat them. Here I am going to write how celebrating Diwali/Deepavali changed from my childhood till today. We never heard of Lakshmi bombs when we were very small. Not only me but even my husband when he was small. Since my husband was born few years before me, I asked him what crackers they crackled during his childhood. So he told me about one interesting thing with which they played with, in their childhood. It was called ‘rolu rokali (pestle and pounder)’ It was like a kitchen tongs, a slight depression on one side and a protrusion on other side. Sound making chemical mixtures were sold in the market. Kids used to place a pinch of that powder in the depression and then hook the clip to other side of the tongs. After tightening they would hit it on the ground forcefully. It would make big sound. It looked like this:  I never saw the above thing, For crackling we had small bindi sized crackles which we called ‘kepulu’(shot gun caps) A small amount of chemical powder was kept between two layers of paper and the layers were glued together. Those shot gun caps were sold in small thick paper boxes which were the size of a rupee coin. We would take one after other and hit them with a hammer or any heavy object and it would give some sound. For sparkling we had colored match boxes or ‘matabulu’ These are matabulu. But they were not in those color paper tubes. Gun powder was stuffed in tubes made with newspapers.  And then there were ‘Tataku patasu kayalu” which are crackers made with palm leaf. These would go up in the air like today’s rockets.  When I was about six-seven years old we saw for the first time ‘Diwali pistol’ My father bought only one pistol, to be shared by we all three sibling. Fourth one was still a baby. We would keep one cap at a time in the pistol and fire. Two or three years later we saw rolls of those shot gun caps.  We got excited to see that we could use the pistol continuously without opening it every time. When my father got a good job in Singareni companies, we could buy variety of crackers like kakara puvvottulu, seema tapakayalu, lakshmi bombs, rockets, vishnu chakram, bhoo chakram , chichu budlu etc.  But we saw real Deepavali in 1962–63, when we had stayed for one year in bobbli for our studies. That year we saw how crackers are made at home. My cousins and all their friends made crackers at home. It was just like a home industry! Coal powder was first made by burning light wood (which is used for packaging) and strained through a fine cloth. Then all chemicals were mixed in certain proportions in it. Then this gun powder was stuffed in peanut shells (after removing the pulp from them by making a small hole) and wood apple (velakkaya in Telugu) shells. While peanut shell bombs made not=so-loud sound, Wood apple bombs mage huge sound. The above bombs were fired exclusively by adult kids. For small kids they made these crackers with palm leaves called ‘Tataku tapakayalu’  And they had ‘cracker competition’ between two streets. We were excited and tensed at the same time seeing those competitions. As we grew old still more varieties appeared in the market. Our children enjoyed all those varieties while growing up. After my daughter got married and to her in laws place and son went to USA, we lost interest in crackers. We would just light the diyas. Surprisingly (but for some obvious reason too) my two grand sons are never much interested in crackers. Four years back they have declared that they would celebrate Diwali ‘the pollution free way’ They never touched crackers from then. We are happy for that too. Today’s kids are smart and thoughtful too. So Happy Diwali to you all kids there!

Diwali, which is known as the festival of light, is a festival of victory over good over evil, light over darkness and knowledge over ignorance. In this day, lights in homes are not only for decoration, but this life story also expresses truth. Light eradicates darkness, and when the light of knowledge eradicates the darkness inside you, good in you conquers evil.  How to Diwali is Celebrated? There are many stories related to this festival- Diwali is celebrated mainly to ignite the light of knowledge in every heart, life in every house, to bring a smile on every face. It literally means the line of light. There are many aspects and levels of life. It is very important that you shed light on all of them because if any aspect of your life is dark, your life will never be able to express its fullness. Therefore, in Diwali, rows of lamps are lit to make you aware that every aspect of your life needs your attention and light of knowledge. Every lamp you light is a symbol of virtue. Every human has virtues. Some have patience, some have love, power, generosity: others have the ability to organize people. The manifest value in you is like a lamp. As soon as they are ignited, awakened, it is Diwali. Another feature of Diwali lies in the bursting of secret firecrackers. Many times in life you are like firecrackers, ready to read bitterly with your suppressed feelings, frustration and anger. When you suppress your rage and hatred, hatred reaches the limit of reading. Firecrackers were used by our ancestors as a psychological practice to express the feelings of people. When you see the explosion outside, you experience similar sensations inside you. A lot of light comes out with the explosion. When you are free from your suppressed feelings, then you become empty and the light of your knowledge arises. Knowledge is required everywhere. If even one family member is in darkness, you cannot be happy. Therefore, you have to establish the light of knowledge in every member of your family. With this, take every member of society, reach every person of the earth. When true knowledge emerges, celebration occurs. In most celebrations we give our awareness or concentration. To maintain the awareness in the festival, our sages have associated each festival with purity and methods of worship. Hence, Diwali is also a time for worship. The spiritual aspect of Diwali brings seriousness to the festival. There should be spirituality in every festival because the festival inferior to spirituality is discrete. ( 500+ word speech and essay on diwali)

This answer is on someone's special request. My day was quiet hectic as you know Diwali ki prepration. I was very tired and I was not in mood of Diwali celebration. My mother said go and take rest and enjoy the celebration after getting up. I was lying on my bed and my brother comes to me and said I've a surprise for you. Wake up and be ready within 2 minutes.  Believe me I got the best surprise. My brother took me to an orphanage. I never enjoyed my Diwali like this. I never felt soo happy.I can't express my feelings in words. I enjoyed alot with those kids/children. We played some games,some of them share their stories and we were pulling each other leg’s. I did not even think for a minute that I am meeting these children for the first time, it felt like we have known each other for so long. I never ever forget this Diwali and I'll try to celebrate every Diwali with these children.  We always keep saying that we have this problem, we have that problem.Go and meet those orphaned children, talk to them and then think if you really have problems in your life or it's just your mindset regarding that situation. Yesterday I learned one thing, in our life we have everything that we need, yet we Complaints for many things. But those orphans do not complaint and enjoy their lives better than us.Those orphans teach us how to live life. I meet a girl there. I have seen very few girls like her. That girl was smarter than me, more sensible and matured than me. We became good friends in a few hours of meeting. I thought that on the occasion of my birthday, I will go and meet these children but due to some health issue I'm unable to go there but I'll surely go there again and spend some quality time with those amazing children. You don't always need a logical reason for doing everything in your life. Remember you are the CEO of your life. 💞🤗😊🤗😊💞

This is how a Hindu community celebrates Diwali/Tihar in Sikkim. This may be true to Nepal as well. We share same culture and language and maybe very distant ancestry too. ‘Tihar’ literally means festival in Nepali language (Nepali is lingua franca of Sikkim). This is the only festival that is named ‘festival’. So you can imagine how festive it can get. Tihar is also called yamapanchak. Preparation starts long before- with planting the flowers at home ,with calculation that it blooms fully on Tihar. Marry gold is the most preferred flower. Though they do not have so pleasant smell but you love it, and whenever you smell it, it gives you the nostalgia of Tihar. Then comes the pre-tihar phase, you are forced by your mother/grandmother to clean every corner of the house. Houses should be painted bright. Garden should be clean and colorful with flowers. All utensils should shine. “You should see your reflection in those utensils” -that sort of order we get. By this time winter is already knocking on the door. The cold weather, blue skies and yellow paddy fields compliments all the decoration you did to your home. Your body glows with the yellow rays of weak sun, so mild and pleasant that you can sit for hours beneath it, enjoying the aura of surrounding. Then starts the five days long festival.  First day: Kaagh Tihar First day is dedicated to crow. This day signifies start of festival. Crows and ravens are worshiped by offerings of sweets and dishes placed on the roofs of houses. Kaagh tihar itself has no much significance but the real preparation of tihar starts this day. People take out old Chinese decorative item including the most famous flickering colorful lights. Some buy new diyas and some wash and dry old diyas. Generally, the design of lights and diyas is the responsibility of youngest or young member of family.  Second day: Kukur Tihar Second day is dedicated to dog, men’s best friend. No matter you like dogs or not (Seriously who hates dogs :P), you have to worship this creature this day. People offer garlands, tika and delicious food to dogs. Pet and street dog both alike. Decoration continues this day. Family gathers in the sun and make garlands. You pick those flowers you planted for these days(Or you buy it if it is not enough). You are given a needle and a thread. You make garlands, and use them to decorate house. You search for extension chords and wires and you decorate the lights all over your house.  Third day: Gai (Cow)Tihar and Laxmi Puja This day is the most important of all five days. The core of tihar. Day starts with the worshiping cows, garlanding and feeding them with the best grass/fodder. Cow is considered synonym to goddess mother Laxmi. On the day Doorways and windows are decorated with garlands made of sayapatri (marrygold) and makhamali (Globe-amaranth) flowers. You fill diyas with oil. By now everything is ready and house is decorated. So you start planning for Deusi and bhailini (I will come to it later) This is the time you were waiting all these days. In the evening, after you lit all diyas and lights,Laxmi, the goddess of wealth is worshiped with mantra and aaratis who is thanked for all the benefits that were bestowed on the families.People pray for prosperity. All the lights, jhilimili, crakers (Sikkim government banned crackers now) and smiling faces irrespective of old/young make it one unforgettable night. Euphoria is complimented by the taste of sail roti(special traditional delicacy).  After laxmi puja is done in your house, you expect the groups of bhailini and deusi, Bhailo is generally sung by girls, while Deusi is sung by boys. It is just like carol. This traditional song has a specific tune. Though you can play around with lyrics not with the tune. This group of children and teenagers (sometimes even old) sing the songs and dance as they go to various homes in their community all night long, covering their whole body to block the chilling cold, collecting money, sweets, food and giving blessings for long life at the end of these songs, the elder of the house serve food and give money to these deusi/bhailo singers and dancers. In return, the Deusi/Bhailo team gives blessings for high income and prosperity. We used to be very exited about this when we were kids. Best part was after it gets over when you distribute the money you have collected. You already have enough pocket money for the month. Those who do not play deusi bhailo plays cards and stays all night up to receive blessings from deusi/bhailo and give them money. This continues for next day also.  Day Four: Goverdhan/ Goru(oxen) Puja Fourth day is dedicated to oxen where oxen is worshiped. People worship Goverdhan mountain also. Deusi is played at night. Again this day has no much significance. People start preparing for fifth day. Women collect the best selected flowers and make garlands for their brothers.  Day Five: Bhai tika If Laxmi Puja is core of tihar, Bhai tika is the Soul of Tihar. Sometimes people say tihar synonym to Bhai tika in general conversation. It is our Rakhi. Brothers travel to thier sister this day no matter how far she lives. Sisters make a special garland for their brothers from a flower that wilts only after a couple of months, symbolizing the sister's prayer for her brother's long life. Brothers sit on the floor while their sisters perform their puja . The puja follows a traditional ritual in which sisters circle brothers, dripping oil on the floor from a copper pitcher and applying oil to their brother's hair, following which a seven-colour tika is applied on the brother's forehead. Next, brothers give tikas to their sisters in the same fashion with an exchange of gifts.Those without a sister or brother join relatives or friends for tika. This day everyone in street will be wearing tika, garland, happy faces strengthening the relationship between brothers and sisters  May this Diwali bring happiness and prosperity in everyone’s life. Subha Tihar everyone! All the images are taken from google.

This article was written by Chandraprakash Shah. I have found it really informative. It is a fuller explanation than I have received to date, explaining why Jain celebrate Diwali. There are about eight days during the Dipavalee celebration in Jainism. It begins on Dhan Terash and ends on Gyan Pancham or Labh Pancham or Shrut Panchami. There are last three days of Ashwin month and first five days of Kartik month. There are five Kalyanak celebrations of each Tirthankara. They are:1. Chyavan (Entering womb of mother)2. Janma (Birth)3. Diksha (Initiation)4. Kevalgyan (Omniscience)5. Nirvan (Emancipation) All are very auspicious occasions and are celebrated with the presence of heavenly gods. Except the last, Kalyanak. This is when the Tirthankara attains emancipation. The people and gods are very happy in the company of Tirthankara as they obtain purest form of knowledge. They can remove their doubts, realize their past, present and future happenings. When Tirthankara emancipates practically all glamour and happiness vanishes. Bhagwan Mahavir knowing his emancipation very near approached Pavapuri alias Apapa town. The heavenly gods created Samosaran (beautiful dome). Bhagwan Mahavir sat on golden throne inside Samosaran. There were twelve beautiful qualities surrounded him. It was Kali Chaudash. His principal eleven disciples were present including Gautamswami. Heavenly gods and goddesses, other people too were present. He had royal patronage too. Rich financiers and merchants, kings, queens and princes and their ministers were followers of Mahavir. Some of them were present to witness the last moments and last discourses of Mahavir. One of them was king Punyapal. He had received eight dreams the night before. Punyapal told Mahavir that he had become scared after having these dreams. He narrated them before Mahavir and requested Mahavir to forecast its results. We shall deal each dream separately in detail later on. But the mention of eight dreams is of important and hence I provide the names of them. They are:1. Elephant2. Monkey3. Kshirvruksha4. Crow5. Lion6. Lotus7. beej (Seed)8. Kumbha (Pot) These dreams seem to be beautiful but the forecast was horrible and it related to entire Jain four fold organizations and universe. Mahavir gave discourses for 16 Praharas continuously i.e. two days and two nights without any break. In these 16 praharas he spoke on 55 chapters of Punya (merits) and 55 chapters of Paap (demerits). These are well-known as Uttaradhyayan Sutra in Jainism. Mahavir also forecasted the horrible future of fifth and sixth Aras of present Avasarpini. As soon as the time for emancipation reached nearer Mahavir asked Gautam to go to a farmer named Devsharma and enlighten his soul with knowledge. This was the day of Amavasya in the month called Ashwin. At midnight on that day Mahavir attained emancipation and relinquished this universe forever. He sat on the deat of salvation. He will never return from there. His emancipation caused extinguishes of Bhav Deepak and turned the atmosphere into darkness and hence those who were present at that time lighted Dravya Deepak. Dipavalee festival since then commenced for Jains. It is celebration of NIRVANA KALYANAK and not enjoyment of worldly pleasures. Why? Because we wish to have NIRVANA as early as possible. Later on Gautamswami returned after meeting Devsharma. He learnt about emancipation of Mahavir and began crying. He then went into deep thinking and converted these thoughts into meditation and concentration of non-attachments. At the dawn of first day of the new month i.e. Kartik he achieved luminous and brilliant kevalgyan (Omniscience). Heavenly gods celebrated his kevalgyan with all gaiety and pleasures. Jains participate in a gorgeous procession on the second day of new month of Kartik every year. In British rule, in Kolkatta, the procession of Bhagwan Mahavir was the scene of gaiety and pleasures for all communities. It was moved through the entire town and halting at Shitalnath Temple. Now let us observe how Jains celebrate Dipavalee: ·         On Dhan Terash: Jain Merchants carry out Puja of Dhan (Money) and their books of accounts. They prefer to close down their shutters after this Puja and Pujan for eight days. ·         On Kali Chaudash: Most of the Jains start observing fast for two consecutive days, preferably women. They sit in Jaap means counting rosary at night. Some go to listen Diwaleekalp. Some enter in to Paushadh (behave like a nun) for two days. ·         On Amavasya Day: People go to the derasar to worship and meet each other. They distribute clothes, give donations and again at night, they sit in Jaap. The Jaap mantra is MAHAVIRSWAMI PARGATAY NAMAH ·         On New Years day people greet each other and express best wishes for the forthcoming New Year. As midnight passes those doing Jaap start chanting “GAUTAMSWAMI KEVAL GNYAYA NAMAH” ·         On the second day of New Year there is a procession of an idol of Mahavir. This is called Bhai Beej. ·         On the third day of New Year, the derasars (Jain temples) and jina idols are decorated with flowers. ·         On the fourth day of New Year people visit the derasar and pray. ·         On the fifth day of New Year it is Gyan Panchami or Shrut Panchmi. On this day Jains worship “Gyan” with different materials, sweets and fruits. They also count rosary to gain pure knowledge. Therefore Dipavalee for Jains is quite different to the way others celebrate it.Jains do not explode crackers.They do not believe in extravagant spending on Dipavalee festival.They believe in making donations to charity.It is also called accounts squaring or balancing merits and demerits.Jains avoid colossal violenceThey observe fastThey worship the Tirthanakaras’ images,They decorate the Jina temples,They observe Jaaps,And businessmen keep their shutters closed.

Yes, Diwali has been always a special festival to us Indians. Colours of Rangoli, Lights, candles, earthen lamps, crackers and sweets make this festival very close to everyone's heart.  But this Diwali, Our team from Sinter Plant consisting the 3A’s, Ajay, Anish (myself) and Ayan, added a new element of skill to the fortress, we work in. We decided to take part in the Rangoli competition of Essar for the first time in the 10 historical years of our plant. As it was our first time participation, we thought why not try something different, really unique to the concept of Rangoli, which would be different from the traditional Rangoli. As a primary response, we engineers sat together in a round table meeting and started a session which we technically call, “The Brainstorming Session”. After the discussion we concluded that we will use colours of nature that mother Earth provides us for making the Rangoli. But this was just an idea which had to be implemented and should take the shape that we wanted to show, the tuff part was yet to come. The second difficult part was due to time limit for completing the idea just in 1 and a half day, performing our on duty job was a challenge for us, so we counted on our extra hours and lunch timings. So we divided our jobs as to finish it quickly enough. Me being the operational guy would take care of the Raw materials, Ajay Bhai and Ayan would take care of the initial drafting of the picture we wanted to project as a Rangoli.  Next day the hard work started I screened out the required quantity of the different waste material of our steel plant which was having it's own unique colour, while Ajay Bhai and Ayan started making the initial projection of the picture on the decided place. First we developed the outer structure with multiple square block divisions and then started giving it the perfect linings for the Rangoli, using the techniques of engineering drawings artistically. Myself and Ayan were the amatuer guys having a little experience of rangoli, while Ajay Bhai was our sole guide in the work out.  The next step was to add colours that were made from screening of waste materials perfectly to suit the monochormatic picture, we had planned for our Rangoli. Intially we had a lot of trouble handling the materials as it is not soft and easily controllable like processed powder colours that are available in market. Somehow we carried on using different techniques, tired sometimes but being helped on by different persons of our plant to fulfill our project, which was the best part, even though they were not responsible or had nothing to gain everyone helped us.  Slowly and steadily, it started to gain its shape, the monochormatic colour views were now getting visible. The hard work that everyone gave in it made the idea we had, practical and finally visible on the surface of the ground. We wanted to create the replica of our own plant view and it somehow worked out due to every participant in making the Rangoli.  Although, we didn't win any prize for our Rangoli in the competition and neither was it a bright picture like everyone else's, but we are proud of the team work we showed to complete the unique idea within just one and a half day. The judges appreciated the uniqueness of the idea we had and said beautiful words for our hard work, which was worth a prize. We celebrated our Diwali around it, everyone taking pictures around it and distributing sweets to each other.  This was us starting this year's Diwali with our own style. Do you know what is the most astonishing fact about this Rangoli ? The total cost of this Rangoli project was just 30Rs. Now this is why team Sinter Plant saves a lot of cash. Wishing everyone a very Happy Diwali. Pic Source : My mobile.

Diwali or Deepawali, is a Festival of Lights that is celebrated with much joy and enthusiasm by Hindus all over the world. It is a time for cleaning the houses, getting together with neighbors, family and friends. Diwali is a time to share sweets with each other and remember that the light of God always triumphs over darkness. happy diwali 2020 images Diwali is celebrated differently in different regions of India. It is the most famous of all the Hindu Festivals. It falls on the (no moon day) of the Hindu month of Kartik –October/November.happy diwali 2020 images  On Diwali day, Hindus light rows of lamps around their houses and draw elaborate sand paintings called rangolis outside their homes. The Goddess of Wealth, Maha Laxmi is also honored. Houses are cleanedNew clothes are wornFirecrackers and fireworksGifts are exchangedBaths in holy rivers and oil baths are doneNeighbors, family and friends come togetherBlessings of elders is soughtDiwali marks the triumphant return of the Supreme Lord Shree Ram and the Mother of the Universe Sita to Ayodhya, amidst fireworks and lighting of lamps by the residents of Ayodhya.happy diwali 2020 images  When Shree Ram was entering the city, all the citizens wished to meet Him first. Seeing their desire, He multiplied Himself into as many forms as there were people and met them all simultaneously. Each person felt that God had come to them first. This was the scene as Lord Ram returned to Ayodhya, and it is to commemorate this event that we decorate with lights on Diwali. We are meant to feel that we are decorating in anticipation of God’s arrival in our homes and in our hearts.happy diwali 2020 images In addition to the cultural significance and celebrations, Diwali also carries a deep philosophical meaning. Light (prakash) symbolizes God, goodness and knowledge – whereas darkness (tam) symbolizes evil, ignorance and maya. The more we bring God into our heart, the more His Divine Light shines within us, relieving us from the effects of the darkness of ignorance, revealing spiritual knowledge, and filling our life with true joy.happy diwali 2020 images May the festival of Diwali also remind us to illumine our intellects with the light of the knowledge of God, and dispel the darkness of material conditioning. HAPPY DIWALI!!!!!!2020 for more details- ehappydiwali2020.blogspot.com

We Celebrate Diwali Festival always at our Native Place. These Year we have Celebrated Diwali Festival at our Village viz Jaswantgarh (2 Hrs away from Naguar) Rajasthan. It was too cold here at 16 degree celsius. On the Auspicious day of Diwali we had done pooja by 7 in the Evening. After that Dinner at 7.30 ( In village we Follow the Rule of “Early to bed Early to Rise Keeps Man Healthy and Wise.”) After we had burned lots of Crackers… and taken tonns of Selfies..  After that we Played “Chitti Khela” (Type of Lottery) in which you buy tickets and you get prize if your name has came. (Prizes are Soaps, Lotion,etc) And Next is My Favourite Part.. The festival of lights, Diwali, is arguably India’s biggest religious celebration, when homes, institutions and entire neighborhoods are decorated with candles, earthen lamps and fairy lights on this auspicious moonless night. In urban India, Diwali has come to be associated with weeks of card parties that culminate in a grand evening of fire crackers, on the main day of the festival. A homogeneous culture has set in with the modern youth that sees the festival as a time for exuberance and conspicuous consumption. Traditionally, however, different regions of India have diverse ways of commemorating this day. Different parts of India celebrate Diwali in their own unique ways. Read on to find out where you can travel to explore these interesting Diwali traditions across India. Uttar Pradesh  Lord Rama's home Ayodhya now lies in the state of Uttar Pradesh, where the Festival of Lights is one of the most widely and enthusiastically celebrated festivals. In Varanasi specially, Diwali is an elaborate affair, with the special evening Ganga Aarti, which lights up the entire Ganga with the thousands of earthen lamps which float over the surface. As the evening is brought on by chants from priests, people welcome Diwali by lighting firecrackers and lighting up their homes with diyas. It is truly an experience to celebrate Diwali in the largest state of India! Places to Visit: Varanasi, Haridwar Maharashtra  It is said that Lord Rama stayed in Panchvati for the major part of his 14 year exile. That place is now close to Nasik, in the state of Maharashtra. The mythological connection aside, Maharashtra celebrates Diwali with great vigour. On Diwali day, Lakshmi-pujan is celebrated on the Diwali evening, where it is believed that Goddess Lakshmi visits the households, bringing with her lots of wealth and prosperity. Mouth-watering delicacies like chakali, shankar-pale, anarse, kadaboli, karanji, shev, and more are served during Diwali, and Marathis hang 'Akash-dive'”outside, to light up their homes. Places to Visit: Mumbai, Pune, Nasik Tamil Nadu ​While most of the country associates Diwali festivities with bursting of crackers at sundown, in Tamil Nadu, this happens by day. People awake at the crack of dawn to have a traditional oil bath. Fragrant pepper, betel leaves and other ingredients are infused with hot oil for a pre-bath massage. After bathing, new clothes are worn and a tonic called ‘Deepavali Lehiyam’ is had as a precursor to the feast ahead. Then, bursting of crackers and sparkles ensues. Celebrations here actually wind up by evening – the time festivities hit their peak in other parts of India. Most Tamilians celebrate this day as the death of Narakasura, a feared demon, at the hands of Lord Krishna. Places to Visit: Chennai, Rameshwaram Bengal In Kolkata, and the rest of the state of West Bengal, this day is referred to as ‘Kali Puja’. An avatar of goddess Durga, Kali is much revered among Bengalis for her formidable presence. Devotees and tantric practitioners alike worship her. People congregate at neighbourhood venues late into the evening, usually to feast on a sacrificial goat. Thereafter, the prayers and rituals commence and carry on late into the night. Homes are adorned with traditional rangoli made with powdered rice and diyas. Fire crackers are burst to welcome the goddess who is an embodiment of a dark and dynamic feminine force. Places to Visit: Kolkata  Andhra Pradesh While many states in India observe this day as the death of Narakasura, in Andhra Pradesh festivities include theatre and drama similar to that of Dussehra. The slaying of the demon is re-enacted by protagonists that play Satyabhama, the consort of Lord Krishna who killed him. Cracker stuffed effigies depicting Narakasura are burnt during these skits. Legend has it that the fiend’s dying wish was to live for one more day in the grandest way possible. Thus fireworks, feasts and festivities are meant to fulfil this desire. There is a lot of emphasis on buying items and gifting. Shop owners treat customers like gods and specially decorate marketplaces to welcome buyers. Places to See: Hyderabad, Hampi Source: Do You Know How Diwali Is Celebrated Across India? Are you ready for celebrating this Diwali on the next level? India’s biggest festival ‘Diwali-Festival Of Lights’ . The five-day festival commemorates the victory of good over evil and is an occasion for prosperity and family togetherness. Glimmering diyas, glittering lamps, colorful rangoli, delicious sweets, firecrackers, these is the way we celebrate Diwali. But, do you know how Diwali is celebrated among different tribal communities? No bursting of crackers and no sweets ! It is wonderful to know how these tribes celebrate Diwali. Chattisgarh : The tribal habitats in Bastar district of Chattisgarh are distinctly identified for their different way of Diwali celebration, known as Diyari. The festivity begins ceremoniously with the marriage of crop in fields with an idol of Lord Narayana. It is followed by the ritual of filling households with food grain. The cattle owners in the tribal community of Bastar are honored with liquor on the first day of the celebration. They offer garlands, paddy, and khichdi, a kind of porridge with local flavor, to the shepherds. They perform Gotton puja, another integral part of the festivity, to seek divine blessings for the good health and protection of their cattle. The cattle are adorned with garlands, the drums are beaten, and the crop is worshiped as an image of Goddess Lakshmi during the 3-day long Diwali celebration.  Odisha : The tribal folks of Odisha, on the occasion of Diwali, seek the blessings of their ancestors who are believed to be living somewhere in the sky after the demise of their mortal bodies on earth. The ritualistic manner of worshiping ancestors is unique to their cultural heritage. “Kaunria Kathi” is one of the rituals that they perform during the festivity. As per the ritual, they burn jute stems to create fire as a signal to summon the ancestors and request for their blessings. We are one of the few communities in Kerala who traditionally celebrate Diwali, (we call it Dīpāvali or shortened as Dīvāḷi) although not the only community in Trivandrum, where I live now. Diwali is more of a cultural day (kind of “new year”) and celebration rather than a religious day for us. We celebrate the religious Diwali rather on Kārtikā Pūrṇima - Kārtikā kṛttikā days (called Kārtikai dīpam or Tṛkkārtika), thereby preserving an older tradition in India. Only that since we follow the solar calendar, the solar Kārtika trails the lunisolar Kārtikā by almost a month. The preparations for Diwali start two-three days before when we prepare sweets and snacks for the celebration. There is a very Diwali-specific sweet called the okkārappoṭi (the Okkārai powder) which is a unique sweet. We make a variety of burfi or the iconic Mysore Pāk too. For savoury, it is usually the “mixture”, a kind of “sevai” with several ingredients mixed. Or other versions of the “sevai” idea like the kārasevai or our more traditional tenkozhal, muṛukku etc. My mother is so interested in making things, so she makes other sweets like atirasam too with these. We Iyers live to eat, so it makes sense why we have sweets and snacks for almost everything under the calendrical sun. We also make a medicinal preparation on the day before Diwali, much like the way of celebrating “Dhanvantari”, which is called “lehyam” or “marunt”. So, on the night before Diwali, we start the fireworks. I personally am interested only in noiseless stuff. The noisy crackers are a pain to the ears. On Diwali day, we rise up early (around the brāhma muhūrtam) and get ourselves wholly drenched in sesame oil. (Coconut oil for hair) Then we have an elaborate bath. Either Idli or Dosa is made, and with the sweets we eat it. (Of course that is the main celebration for Iyers) Then we start the fireworks. Usually, we buy new clothes before Diwali and wear them that day (Dīpāvalikkōṭi). In Tiruvalla, we were the only family in the neighborhood who celebrated Diwali. However, in Trivandrum city (agrahārams esp.) the celebration is insane. You cannot sleep due to the “bombs”. For me, personally, Diwali is one of the first festivals that I remember from my toddler-hood. I have followed a personal tradition in Diwali, to sing all my songs and play my music, since my first song was finalized in my third year on a Diwali. :) Happy Dīpāvali to all those who celebrate. May Agni and the Kṛttikās get us through a hundred bright autumns.

And you can take it up a notch by gathering your social circles to hand paint diyas with natural dyes as a fun exercise.  4. For Jains, Diwali is an important festival which also carries religious fervour.This is because Bhagwan Mahaveer, the 24th Tirthankar in the current cycle,  had achieved nirvana/Moksha on this day, in the wee hours of the morning(according to Jain calendars) at Pawapuri in current Bihar.  Moksha Kalyanak is a very important and the last Kalyanak amongst the 5 kalyanas in the life of any Tirthankar, the list of which is:1. Garbha Kalyanak2. Janma Kalyanak3. Tapa Kalyanak4. Gyan Kalyanak5. Moksha Kalyanak. On this day, Jain people from around the city, go to temples in the morning hours, starting from as early as 5:30 A.M. and continuing till noon. Idol of lord Mahaveer is anointed and Puja, Arghya, Ashtak, Aarti,  devotional songs and Mantras are sung. A special offering consisting of Til(Sesame) laddu, fruits like custard apple, banana, apple, Amla(Indian Gooseberry) and batasha(Indian confectionery) is made to Bhagwan Mahaveer in the morning prayers. The offering signifies observation of renunciation by the lord, and is taken to be an inspiration to reduce one's greed. All of these offerings are then donated to the poor, or handed over to charitable institutions.  Also, the chief disciple of lord Mahaveer, Gautam Gandhar had attained Moksha in the evening on the same day. (Each Tirthankar has his/her own Gandhar, the chief disciple who in the Samavsharan, asks questions to lord and delivers his teachings to all the beings present. The Samavsharan or the divine pavilion is an extraordinary creation made by the Kuber on request by the Indra, and it occurs after Gyan Kalyanak and before the Moksha Kalyanak of any Tirthankar See this: on www.jainsamaj.org ( Jainism, Ahimsa News, Religion, Non-Violence, Culture, Vegetarianism, Meditation, India. )). In the rest of the day,  almost like any other household, we exchange sweets and greetings. There is also an emphasis on reducing/not using crackers as Jainism considers that this harms the living organisms in the environment.  Our houses are lit with both earthen lamps and series of colourful electrical lights which dazzle in the night, and a significant attraction is the sky lantern, a colourful lantern made of cloth, paper and/or cardboard, which adorns the balconies and/or verandah. Beautiful coloured Rangolis are drawn on the floors at the entrance doors. This is an image which just attempts to paint the Samavsharan, but the actual grandeur is difficult to be drawn, due to the magnificence and grandness of the occurring and also the geographical expanse of the gathering.

Here in IIT Kgp Diwali is celebrated in a grand manner. We don’t get week long holiday so the festival is celebrated in the campus itself. We have our own unique way of celebrating Diwali. Here the festival is called Illumination or Illu for short. Instead of burning fireworks wooden mesh filled with diyas are prepared. Diyas are arranged in the mesh to form several magnificent images. Preparation starts as early as 5–6 weeks before the festival. Every hall (hostels) makes huge rangolis and mesh structures which are lit on the day of Diwali. All this is done without burning a single firecracker. And the satisfaction we get from seeing our hard work pay off is far more greater than amusement from burning firecrackers. I won’t write much because a picture is worth a thousand words. Here are some images of Illumination - 2018          We also make huge Rangolies.       These are black chart panels with cutouts illuminated by diyas     Image Credits: Click Kgp and my phone gallery.

Today it is all about dieting prior to the opening up of the festive season.... so let us be more careful here are some very useful handy tips... to see through the festive season and the whole year too.....here we go........👍The new dieter’s 10 commandments: 1. If you eat something and no one saw it – it has no calories. 2. When you eat with someone else, the calories don’t count if they ate more. 3. Tasting someone else’s food doesn’t count. 4. If people around us gain weight, we automatically become thinner. 5. If your movie ticket comes with a free tub of popcorn, it doesn’t count as food. 6. Every food you split into smaller pieces will contain less calories. 7. Tasting food while preparing it is essential, and therefore – healthy. 8. Foods with similar colors contain the same amount of calories. This is why it’s fine to eat pistachio ice cream instead of spinach. 9. Chocolate has a dedicated area in the stomach, which is why you should have it with every meal. 10. Frozen foods, such as ice cream, contain no calories. The reason is that a calorie is a measurement of heat units.😋😋😋😋😋😋😋😋😋😋😋 be happy in diwaali seasonHappy diwali....

response.answer_text: MBA life is hectic and that too gets exaggerated when you are in IIM. Busy schedules, daily assignments and regular submissions are like never ending EMIs and to be continuously submitted. Festivals are like a sigh of relief in these mundane daily businesses, not because you get a day off, rather, because you got to see something interesting. Something creative, and beautiful, something created just because everyone wants to get involve in it. No we do not breathe in and breathe out business, we too need to enjoy these lights and sounds.  We are in a part of India where you can't figure it out that it's Diwali, until and unless, it's Diwali day only. But at IIM hostel, the atmosphere was all charged with light works and lighted up with those earthen lamps. It was beautifully decorated and was telling its own story of passion and joy, standing in a mundane street, with a complete makeover.   The hostel was not only lighted in a beautiful veil from outside but some amazing display of creativity can be found even inside of the hostel. Rooms were decorated beautifully to resonate with the Diwali atmosphere.  Sometimes, noise brings with itself a sense of happiness. Happiness in sharing the joy, happiness of having fun in lighting up those crackers and enjoying the last run when it is about to burst.  So, this is our story of celebration. An event to rejoice together, laugh together and perhaps hug together for all those bits of joys that are tattered in daily rush of life.  Happy Diwali! Diwali celebration in India 2020 – The Festival of Lights is undoubtedly one of the most awaited festival for most Indians. It is celebrated all over India and has different names and spelled differently. Deepawali, Deepavali or Diwali it could be anything in different parts of India. But the meaning is still the same as Deep is Light and vali is row – so it means something like a row of lights. The entire country gets illuminated with these colorful lights on the Biggest Festival in India. It is a four day festival and Diwali 2020 falls on Saturday, 14 November. Be part of the dazzling colors and lights this Diwali celebration in India. How is Diwali is celebrated in India? How Diwali is celebrated in India depends mainly on the region where it is celebrated. It is not only celebrated within India but in most countries where Hindus celebrate world over especially in Asia. The significance is different based on the region. However, the celebrations of fireworks at night, lighting diya in and outside houses, drawing and decorating outside the gate, puja and rituals, are mostly common. There are vast preparation for Diwali, shopping for Diwali, exchanging sweets or gifts, wishing each other and sharing love, etc. Homes are illumined with diya, deepam, or earthen lamps. The smell of sweets getting prepared and fresh flowers comes from almost all homes during Diwali. People clean their houses thoroughly before decorations. The streets are filled with children and families playing with fireworks – bursting crackers, ladis, special candles, etc. As the evening comes the streets are filled with noise of the loud crackers burst by kids in the neighborhood. When it gets dark, the entire family or the members of family who come out and light various types of fireworks, some which make sound and some which do not. It is a sight that nobody can describe. You have to come see and experience this Diwali celebrations in India. In addition to all these celebrations, there are small groups or area community who also organize huge and massive celebrations in various states in India. This includes huge cut-outs and puppets or people dressed in mythological costumes who stage road shows or plays. The characters enact various scenes of different reasons on Why Diwali is celebrated or the significance of Diwali Significance of Diwali Celebration in India Significance of Diwali Celebration in India Each and every Diwali ritual has a specific significance. The people burst firecrackers to celebrate victory. They light crackers and fireworks to show their happiness and joy. In different regions in India, people have various beliefs and reasons why Diwali is celebrated. Beyond the lights, crackers and celebrations there are changes people make: Forgive – Forgive the wrong others have done to them. They are friendly and festivity everywhere. Unity in love – The people get united, love and share love with each other. Prosperity – The business people and merchants perform puja for success in their business. Why is Diwali Celebrated in India?  The significance of Deepawali is the victory of Good over Evil from each myth story and legend. People believe that they should illumine their hearts along with their homes during Diwali. It is a belief that they go from darkness into the light by making a commitment to doing good. It is believed that such actions will lead them to divinity. There are People from various religions including Sikhism, Jainism, and Buddhism who also have celebrations of Diwali as important days of the festival. There are various Diwali celebrations around the world this Deepavali 2020. People spread peace and joy by exchanging love and gifts to each other. What to enjoy during Diwali?  Source : Diwali Images 1. Every temple around the country holds unique rituals and celebrations. You can find traditional delicacies served in the temple for the devotees. 2. Every house would be decorated with lights, colorful arts in front of the house with color powder and the sound of bursting crackers. 3. At night, people prefer bursting colorful crackers and rockets. The best way to enjoy Diwali night is by watching the night sky to spot beautiful burst of colors. 4. You can find cultural performances, competitions and others in many places. 5. New movies are released during this day. You can enjoy the art of the land by enjoying a show. Many theaters offer English subtitles for tourists to enjoy the local cinema. 6. You can find numerous unique and exotic sweets, which are specifically made only during Diwali. 7. You can find fairs, exhibitions and mela in all major cities and towns during this celebration. You can find many handicrafts, souvenir items and traditional articles for sale during this exhibition.

Jains celebrate Diwali because 24th and last Tirthankara of this time cycle Lord Mahavira attained Nirwana or salvation on this day. Dhanya Teras We don't call Dhan Teras but we call it Dhanya Teras. It's because that was the last day when Lord Mahavira's divine voice (Divya Dhvani) was heard by his followers as his preachings. He preached for the last time on that day. Hence, that day was dhanya and known as Dhanya Teras. We don't do laxmi puja or book puja. It is considered as mithyatva (wrong belief) by Jains. Kali chaudas Kali chaudas is known as kali chaudas because Lord Mahavira's divine voice stopped on this day because he was going to attain Moksha on the next day. Hence, hos followers stopped getting advantage of his preaching. Diwali or Deepavali On this day more than 2500 years ago, 24th and last Tirthankara Lord Mahavira attained salvation. Tirthankara gets enlightened before attaining salvation. At the end of his lifespan, he atrains salvation (liberation or moksha). When he attains salvation, his body fly above on the top in a circular motion and get dispersed in the atmosphere. Earlier when he was physically present, his divine body was omitting light which was his aura (abhamandal), Also, many heavenly dieties were present in Lord Mahavira”s samavasaran. These heavenly dieties were having illuminating body and wearing shining crowns and jewellery made of diamonds and jewels which were omitting light. Hence, people were never experiencing darkness but when Lord Mahavira attained Moksha on the dawn of Amavasya (Diwali day) from Pawapuri, his body fled and heavenly dieties left the place, due to which that night became very dark. For a few moments, the entire world became dark. To remove the darkness, heavenly beings kept gems and humans lit earthen lamps at their houses. People had mixed feelings. They were sad that Lord Mahavira left them physically but also very happy that he attained liberation or Nirvana and became God. How Jains celebrate Diwali? From that day onwards, Deepavali is celebrated every year to honor and worship the Jinendra (i.e. Lord Mahavira) on the occasion of his nirvana. On Diwali early morning, Nirvan Ladoo offered after praying and doing puja of Lord Mahavira in all Jain temples across the world. (Nirvan ladoo is made of pure sugar or gola of coconut is offered as a symbol of Nirvan ladoo). Nirvan kand bhasha stuti and other hymns, verses and religious songs are sung at the Jain temples. The main principle of Jainism is non-violence, so Jains don't burst firecrackers as it kills lots of insects and microorganisms. Traditionally, Jains lit lamps and diyas in their houses and offices as lights are symbol of knowledge or removal of ignorance. Many jains observe fasting in remembrance of the penance and sacrifice of Mahavira. In the evening, many people do samayik (a kind of Jain religious prayer to introspect all the sins one might have done throughout his life). Jains gives more emphasis on prayers, fasting, penence and simplicity unlike other Hindus who celebrate Diwali with lots of fire crackers, noise, eating out, seeets and songs/dances. Yes, culturally Jains do distribute sweets, lit lamps, and do Rangoli. Lighting lamp is symbolic to remove darkness of ignorance and keeping Lord Mahavira's teachings alive. However, now LED diyas are available so I personally believe in lighting LED diya rather than earthen lamp to avoid pollution. Diwali is celebrated as a tribute to penance and sacrifice of Mahavira and his valuable contributions to the mankind. Jain New Year The following day of Diwali is known as new year. Jain calendar is known as Veer Nirwana Samvat and it is counted from next day of when Lord Mahavira attained liberation. As per Jain calendar, it is 2545 year.

She’s also worshipped as she endows you with blessings of success and promotion and progress in career, trade, business etc.

Kiran Rawat, IUEf English Educator for Pooma Educational Trust. We don’t live in bungalows, duplexes or flats. We live in our minds. Yes, that’s our permanent residence. And there are no constraints of square-feet there. It’s a vast space with unlimited area. And you know what! No matter how well-organized your rooms, balconies, garages and verandas are, life is good only when things are sorted there – in your mind. And that’s where we keep things messy – regrets piling up in one corner, expectations stuffed in a closet, secrets under the carpet, worries littered everywhere, comparisons spilt on the table, complexes leaking from an old bottle, and grudges stinking in a box. Be aware. For this ‘real home’ of yours, you can’t outsource housekeeping. You have got to do it yourself. Lets start with our true "Diwali cleaning".
